subject: Re: [junit] creative use of JUnit
msgSnippet: ... hierarchy ... by ... but ... Generally I agree, but bear in mind that I m not talking of normal unit-tests here. I m testing object hierarchies and
messageBody:
"James Cheesman" <jim@...> wrote on 14.04.2004 09:39:26:

> >>All test-suites I've seen thus far have a very clearly defined
hierarchy
> >>of tests (that is either hand-coded using suite()-methods or generated
by
> >>some kind of find-all-test-cases-in-this-hierarchy-algorithm). In my
> >>little Junit-misuse experiment I don't have such pre-defined hierarchy
but
> >>only decide which tests need to be run when running them (so one test
> >>might dynamically add 3 other tests that need to be run).
>
>
> I have no idea as to whether or not this would work, but I have to ask
> why you would want to structure your tests in this fashion - aren't
> tests better designed as independent as possible of one another?

Generally I agree, but bear in mind that I'm not talking of normal
unit-tests here.

I'm testing object hierarchies and configurations for errors here (not
code) so for example I have 5 objects of type A where each has zero to
five associated objects of type B. I want to run some tests on all objects
of type A and some tests on all objects of type B. Now I could traverse
the whole hierarchy in advance to get a complete overview of the test
hierarchy needed, but it is much simpler to just let the tests themselves
register test-able objects whenever they come across one (additionally the
hierarchy can be much larger and exist in persistent storage, traversing
it twice would be terrible for performance).

Btw, I've finally decided that JUnit is not my tool here, 'cause it makes
some assumptions that I can't/don't want to meet. (Most of these
assumptions can be broken without breaking JUnit itself, but tools that
work with JUnit like Eclipse become confused as hell, when a test returns
more than one error/failure). I'm using many of the design decisions made
for JUnit as a guide, 'though.

regards
Joachim Sauer
